column3: United States;Dubbel;Heavy Seas Brewing Company;It has a deep garnet color body with good clarity and some nice viable carbonation flowing up to the surface. On top is an average size light tan head. It hangs on well as I drink it slowly fades to a thin covering that lasts to the end. On the glass the head leaves behind some spotty lacing. The aroma has a sweet candy like nose that reminds me of cherry flavored Jolly rancher candy. Its flavor has a big malty sweetness with the same cherry candy notes as in the aroma. There is also a slight cherry chough syrup like alcoholic touch in there. Hop bitterness and flavor are mild and really only show up in the finish where they try in vain to balance the malt sweetness. On the palate it has a slightly thin feel for the sweetness and nice average carbonation. Overall I feel this one was a bit on the sweet side with a simple raw character.

column2: Denmark;Strong Ale - American;Amager Bryghus;500 ml bottle Hidden in the back of the cellar I found this well aged bottle. Surprisingly it has held up extremely well though I can tell the edges are a bit rough. If you happen to be sitting on any I would not wait much longer to crack them open. AROMA / APPEARANCE Long creamy legs and a cocoa head pair well with the dense base. Musty sherry feels mellow and cool despite a heady aspect which gives away the near 10% ABV. FLAVOR / PALATE Red wine and dusty chocolates warm the tongue. Soon after a wave of sherry and honey settles in. The full bodied transition borders on cloying yet stays enjoyable. The thick mouthfeel even manages to not overstay its welcome despite this clearly being a nightcap. It would be interesting to have put it up against a fresh bottle for contrast.

column1: Het Anker Gouden Carolus Easter Beer (2007-2009);Mechelen
column2: Belgium;Belgian Ale - Strong Pale;Brouwerij Het Anker;Une bouteille poussiéreuse qui m’attendait dans le fin fond d’une cave. Donc
column3: une certaine appréhension. Un liquide qui dévoile une robe orangée. Un col mousseux bien mince. C’est pardonnable. Un nez qui présente certainement quelques rides. Des malts doux qui compriment les autres parfums. Du sucre belge
column4: indéniablement. L’impression d’un produit qui a connu un élevage oxydatif. Peut-être des épices et des fruits dans le fond de mon verre. Des saveurs qui sont pourtant loin d’être déplaisantes. Des malts qui tiennent le fort. Des saveurs vineuses qui sont touchées par les années. Une bouche encore bien vivante. Une texture douce dans un corps qui n’est pas trop mince. Une finale dans laquelle les vapeurs d’alcool transportent des pointes épicées. Tout compte fait
column5: une bière capable de se défendre devant les inepties de certains brasseurs.

column1: Full Sail Nugget Special Red Ale;Hood River
column3: United States;Red Ale / Intl Amber Ale;Full Sail Brewing Company;From Mar 2008 I got this in a trade with Wasatch. Thanks John! The pour reveals a clear amber with a 1 finger head of foam with a little lacing. Good head retention. The smell has notes of both caramel malt and hops with the malt winning out. Nice nose here. The taste has yummy caramel malt up front with a very nicely done hoppy bitterness midway through that does a heck of a job in the balancing department. I can tell I'm going to enjoy the rest of *this* beer. More sips in and I get some roasted malt that works with the hops in the bittering and again
column4: I'm quite pleased with how the hops and malt are working together. Full Sail sure does make some darned good brews and this one is no exception. The mouthfeel borders on being full and it finishes slightly bitter and has a good aftertaste. Nothing boring about this Amber.. something I can't say about many examples of the style that I've tried in the past. Darn good stuff!!

Malt and hop mingle nicely with an overbaked biscuit sweetness and hop tang on the finish. Mouthfeel is medium to full and the beer is very appetizing for the next sip - very drinkable. I’m having trouble getting past the bread and biscuit components because I love them so much in a beer.

column3: United States;Bock - Weizenbock;Pennsylvania Brewing Company;Nothing shows Pandemonium-but this is a review of Penn’s bottled weizenbock. A- Opaque (seriously) medium brown body with highlights of lighter brown throughout. Pours with a decent 2 finger head which eventually fades completely. No lacing is left behind in the glass. S-Chocolate comes out first
column4: followed by a spiciness
column5: then raisins and plum. A little bit of alcohol comes through too. T-Upfront is some spiciness with a solid yeast backbone. This is followed by a dominant presence of dark fruit (plum and raisins). Finish is consistent with the flavor mentioned (nothing weakens or intensifies) except a hint of chocolate emerges here. What is left to linger is remnants of dark fruit
column6: spiciness and a slight alcohol heat. P-Medium carbonation ans medium-weight body. Initially smooth because of the yeast but the alcohol shines through in the mouthfeel for the finish taking away slightly from the smoothness. O- I like this brew-but honestly think that I should have chosen a different glass. It’s a very good

England;Bitter - Ordinary / Best;Anheuser-Busch InBev UK (AB InBev);On draft at the Hilton (Warwickshire) With limited options to choose from this seemed the most appealing. Time permitting I would have loved to go back to Slaughterhouse but that’s life. The good news is that I have had far worse bitters. A run of the mill pub clip probably sells as good as it does because of the Shakespeare caricature. Don’t be fooled yourself unless it is a freebie. Aroma / Appearance - The caramel base is on the thin fluid side. A khaki head bubbles with a tease of carbonation below the surface. Butterscotch
column4: caramel chews
column5: and light malts stand out. If any hops were used in the brewing process they have faded away into the background. Flavor / Palate - Butterscotch and caramel notes slip past the tongue before anything shows up. Pretty routine it at least has some flavor to it before fading in the back of the throat. There are no glaring flaws. However if you’ve had enough bitters to understand the style you’ve had a number just like this one.

column2: Singapore;Stout - Extra / Foreign;Singapore Brewery (Asia Pacific Breweries-Heineken);This is a terrible beer and should be avoided at all costs! The ginseng is so overpowering and gross that it totally kills this beer. Some things just should not be infused into beer!

column3: frothy and rather retentive light brown head. Weird aroma of burned malt

column2: Singapore;Stout - Extra / Foreign;Singapore Brewery (Asia Pacific Breweries-Heineken);33 cL can. Pours dark brown with a creamy and dense tan head. Ends with a smoth chocolate note with a diminished earthy spice note. Light acidic touch.
Singapore;Stout - Extra / Foreign;Singapore Brewery (Asia Pacific Breweries-Heineken);This beer nearly killed a group tasting. There were eight of us in Sully’s house when he opened two cans of this
column3: and eight of us outside shortly after. The stench of rotting asparagus filled a room and lingered for hours. Just a sip or two of this ginseng-infused stout induced foul burps that tainted all the beers that followed. Weaker men would have quit. Correction
column4: smarter men would have quit. Ginseng may well have life-enhancing medicinal qualities but it has no place in beer. If you ignored the smell long enough to concentrate
column5: this stout looked promising - jet black with a thick lather of suds. But the smell... Green and vegetal. Jalapeno peppers
column6: asparagus and charcoal with a heavy medicinal/mineral taint. It tastes better than it smells

column1: Green Flash Hop Head Red (-2013);San Diego
column3: United States;IPA - Red;Green Flash Brewing Company;"From Sept 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with russpowell. Thanks Russ! This pours a hazy red colour with close to a 2 finger head of foam. Nice lacing. The smell is a nice mix of sweet and bitter. Good caramel malt and pine and citrus hops. The taste follows the nose...strong flavours of both caramel malt sweetness and ample hoppiness with pine being primary and citrus being secondary and I notice some roastiness and some grain after the first couple of sips. Very close to being balanced but the pine just edges out the malt. The mouthfeel is solidly medium as is the carbonation
column4: and it finishes with some roasted malt goodness and just a touch of pine. Nice. Nice and very drinkable. Btw
column5: head retention is quite good as is the lacing. Bottom line: This is definitely one of the better Red/Amber Ales I've tasted to date. I'd like another please. ;^)"

column3: England;Red Ale - Irish;Loddon Brewery;Takeaway from Gravity Cask @ Bitter Virtue
column4: Soton. Browny red with suprisingly resilient head for a beer racked into a plastic bottle. Sweet toffeish biscuity malt with a mild hint of buttery diacetyl which wasnt unpleasant but didnt add anything for me. Light earthy hops with a hint of citrus and a full slightly tannic bitter finish. This cleanses the mouth leaving you ready for another mouthful of sweet maltiness - lovely interplay between the flavours. This was billed by the brewer as an Irish Red ale and was perhaps slightly hoppier than traditional but not too much. Quite good but this is the sort of beer that feels autumnal to me

column2: Italy;BarleyWine / WheatWine / RyeWine;Birrificio Svevo;(Bouteille de 750 ml partagée avec rodenbach99) Le liquide est brun marécageux. La mousse foncée est bien solide et semble vouloir durer éternellement. Le nez présente un malt aux aspirations caramélisées recouvert de vapeurs fruitées douces et aigres. On peut même percevoir des odeurs de petites pastilles médicamenteuses à la cerise. L’alcool s’accroche aux narines comme des petites fleurs malhabiles. Les saveurs me semblent moins intéressantes: les pointes maltées et les fruits sont secoués par des agents aigres et par des accents éthyliques. En bouche
column3: le liquide est en manque de corps avec une effervescence modérée et une texture douce. La finale est acerbe et caustique

column5: dark tan) and showed light lacing (slight ring at the top). Body is a very deep dark-brown mahogany but shows magenta highlights on the edges. Clarity is medium. Controlled roastiness nicely melds with layers of both dark and milk chocolate to create a very lovely complexity and ample malty aroma. Quite a high strength of aroma
column7: being served from a shaker at a crowded brewpub and quite cold to start. Light vanilla and just a hint of licorice-infused coffee dot the finish
column8: adding a bit of poignancy. Soft
column9: mossy/earthy hoppiness adds freshness and further complexity without any bitterness or acids. No alcohol or flaws in the nose. Deliciously rich body is surprising for its gravity. Strong
column10: unfiltered mouthfeel with medium-low carbonation really accentuates the malt
column11: and there’s lots of malt. Mostly chocolatey
column12: but with a dry roasted edge to balance and just a pinch of char and coffee on the finish. Opens up very sweet
column14: with light hop bitterness adding to the roast to further balance things. Very velvety
column15: chocolatey and smooth with no alcohol or flaws apparent. Never gets syrupy
column17: which helps keep the drinkability high. Drank this one down quickly. Nothing groundbreaking on the flavor or aroma
column18: but one of the better balances between rich malt and easier drinkability I’ve come across recently.

column3: United States;Sour / Wild Beer;North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery;Wow...the best by far!!!! column3: United States;Red Ale - Irish;Third Base Sports Bar & Brewery;On tap at the brewpub. Pours a light reddish colored amber with the ubiquitous thin white head of all the beers served here. column1: Third Base Tilted Kilt Irish Ale;Cedar Rapids
column3: United States;Red Ale - Irish;Third Base Sports Bar & Brewery;Draft at the brewpub. Advertised as 22 IBU’s. Poured a clear amber color. Head was off white and reduced relatively quickly into a thin film. A nice curtain of lace was left on the glass at the end. Smelled of malty brown sugar with light sprucy hops in the background. Malt also dominated the flavor with subdued caramel and brown sugar notes. There was also a hint of black tea and a delicate cereal grain aftertaste. I didn’t taste or smell any peated malt in this one
column4: but it was pretty good.

column3: United States;Dubbel;J.T. Whitneys Pub & Brewery;10 oz sample I have been avoiding JT Whitney’s for a while just because there has been nothing compelling on tap. While I would not suggest it over many bottled dubbels it does satisfy. My advice is to let it sit for 20 minutes so the ice on the sides of the cold glass has time to melt. There is a little coffee bitterness in the middle before the hops come back to leave a slightly bitter finish. The mouthfeel is creamy but lighter and with more bitterness than your typical porter. This is one very interesting porter and one that I certainly wasn’t expecting. I can’t put it up there with the better porters out there but it was very enjoyable.

column3: England;Bitter - Ordinary / Best;Old Spot Brewery;A Mes rate: Gravicask at London Drinker. The mostin interesting beer I had at the festival. Very stout like given its (very good) amber looks. It’s a bit of a contradiction but not at all in a negative way. Much darker in character than you would think to look at it. Lovely and roasty all round with heavy sweetish malt. Then all of a sudden dusty and dry with a great hit of hops for some finishing balance. Something a little different and I enjoyed it a lot.

United States;Flavored - Fruit;Willoughby Brewing Co.;On tap at brewpub This was better than the Snowbelt and salvaged a downhill experience. column7: paled sweetness of old citrus and some solid fruitishness and breadyness. Kinda like old pear and mango with a slight tone of wheat germ and the said breadyness of dough. Twist in more left over malts and hearty breadish sweetness and you’ve got a winner in a quick tasty treat the lasts on the palate and endures that want of more. column1: New Belgium Lips of Faith - Chad's Blackberry Ale;Fort Collins
column3: United States;Flavored - Fruit;New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);"22oz bottle filled from the tap at NBB. Another brew from the ""Lips of Faith"" or ""Pilgrimage"" series
column4: it’s brewed with 40% Marion blackberries with an ale yeast in the primary
column5: and finished with a champagne yeast. Pours fizzy and incredibly murky. Almost the color of beet juice. Dark maroon with shades of purple
column6: and thoroughly opaque. No light able to pass through the goblet
column7: even when held directly in front of a light bulb. Unlike any beer I’ve ever seen. The cola-like fizz of head dissapeared in a snap
column8: only being able to catch a glimpse of purple bubbles. Aromatics are mainly fruit juice with a hint of tartness. The Marion berry smells a lot like raspberries but more pungent
column10: and there is some black raspberry presence as well. Mouthfeel is much lighter than expected for such a turbid brew. Fairly crisp and surprisingly dry considering the level of fruitiness. The pallet is basically fermented fruit juice
column11: with a slight bitterness to help balance. Loads of black and red raspberries again
column13: warming quality. Finishes barely puckering at best
column14: with lingering marion berries. This would be a great beer to barrel age with bugs."

ITS like drinking strong champagne with a bunch of hops not recommended for soft drinker PLATE: The ABV.% was at 10.0so that made the beer have an over whelming palate taste the whiskey was no help ether. OVERALL: I would recommend you only drink 1-2 do to the high ABV% very strong but some what sweet tasting cheers!!

column3: United States;IIPA - Imperial / Double IPA;Madison River Brewing Company;Bottle. Smooth and hoppy. It's a bit creamy in after taste. Would recommend ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

United States;IIPA - Imperial / Double IPA;Madison River Brewing Company;"Poured from bottle into a snifter Appearance – The beer pours a clear red tinted orange amber color with a one finger head of foam. The head fades over a moderate level of time to leave a decent level of streaky lace on the sides of the glass. Smell- The aroma of the brew is heaviest of a sweeter fruity aroma being mainly of a melon and tangerine smell. Along with these smells comes some hoppy aromas being mostly a mix of grapefruit and an earthy smell
column4: but also containing a faint floral hop aroma as well. With a bit of a musty smell and a bit of bread
column5: a rather sweet and intriguing aroma is overall produced. Taste – The taste starts with a bready and sweeter fruit flavor with a nice tangerine sweetness upfront. Other sweeter flavors of caramel are upfront as well
column6: being mixed with a good showing of a grapefruit hop. The grapefruit grows stronger in nature as the taste moves on to the end
column7: being accompanied by some herbal and initially lighter pine hop tastes. While the grapefruit is the strongest at the end
column8: the pine does get to a more moderate strength overall. Some slightly musty and a moderately melon taste comes more toward the end of the taste. With a loss of the caramel sweetness and a bit of a dwindling of the tangerine
column9: one is left with a decently hopped
column10: and still smooth and still rather fruity sweet flavor to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the rather more syrupy side with a carbonation level that is on the slightly lower side. For the melon fruity flavors and the hoppy tastes the syrupy body is actually quite nice accentuating the hop and creating a sorta chewy feel for the melon. The thickness coupled with the lower carbonation level of the brew
column11: makes of a nice slow sipping style overall. Overall – This was a very enjoyable double IPA overall. Not the standard citrus bomb that you often get; this one has nice blends of other fruity flavors and a nice blend of hops. Quite enjoyable overall."

column1: The Livery Brandy Cask Aged Cherry Jubilee;Benton Harbor
column3: United States;Flavored - Fruit;The Livery;From a growler and served in my NB worthy glass: A deep murky brownish red hue topped initially by a frothy off-white head which fades to a ring and left good lace. The aroma has a strong bourbon overtone of oak
column4: booze
column6: and sugar along with fleshy cherries and the pits and some wild flowers. The taste starts sort of sweet with those bourbon woody notes along with simple sugar reduction before a rush of ripened cherry takes over providing both sweet and sour components. The finish has a earthy and yeasty nature that lends this beer to be close to a Flemish brown. The mouth feel is sticky and rich with a acidic twang which kept it in balance and a touch dry in the aftertaste. This beer rocks! While not as tart as NG Red or a few of the best Flemish Sour Browns
column7: it is hardly a syrupy sweet American fruit beer. Brandy Barrel-Aged for 6 months
column8: there is a define BA nature to the brew that adds a great depth of palate. Kudos to Steve for this is even better than his Cherry Wheat.

column3: United States;Pale Ale - English;Christian Moerlein Brewing Company;From Aug 2008 I got this in a trade with zapata. Thanks Ben! It pours a clear dark amber with a finger head of foam that quickly shrinks to a fine layer. Good lacing. The smell has some caramel sweetness to it along with some slight floral hop notes. It's on the light side but it's good. The taste is nice! Good caramel sweetness with some biscuit and some grain and I find this is a malt based APA. A few more sips in and the Fuggles hops push some good semi bitterness into the mix. Result. A very tasty and very balanced Pale Ale indeed! Love it and I don't think that there are enough of these types around. Medium mouthfeel and lightish carbonation help to really bring out the flavours. It finishes on the bitter and dry side. And
column4: drinkability is very good. It's 6%abv but I *know* I could drink 2 or 3 of these at a sitting. Here's another interesting and tasty brew from Christian Moerlein. I'm very happy that I decided to seek some out.

column3: United States;Bock- Heller Bock / Maibock;Buzzards Bay Brewing;I had the bottled version

column5: deep straw yellow. The bright white head faded quickly
column6: but left some nice lacing on the glass. This MaiBock’s flavor is intense
column7: but not pleasantly so. The subtlety of this beer’s aromatics don’t translate to the flavors. This beer is way too bitter for a mai bock. Whatever maltiness exists in this beer is covered by a harsh hop bitterness that sits on the tongue. This beer is not gentle on the palate either. A grainy astringency combined with the hop bitterness overpowers any malt sweetness and body that this beer might have. This beer tastes more like a pilsner on steroids
column8: rather than a traditional Mai Bock that highlights a delicate dance of malt sweetness and hop bitterness.

Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture sirupeuse. Faible effervescence en arrière goût. Présence d’érable en arrière goût. (Rating #972)

column1: Bobcat Cafe Buels Gore Black Lager;Bristol
column3: United States;Schwarzbier / Black Lager;Bobcat Cafe and Brewery;My Bottom Line: Chocolatey maltiness and its accompanying roastiness attain equilibrium with the help of a savvy herbal hop spiciness. column3: Canada;Brown Ale;Le Saint-Bock - Brasserie Artisanale;Dégustée en fût sur place sous le nom « La Studieuse ». De couleur brune foncée et semi-voilée. Nez malté de caramel aux notes rôties et terreuses avec des notes de noix grillées ainsi que des traces de chocolat noir
column4: de toffee et de fruits (confitures de fraises). Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-bas et une texture légèrement huileuse et aux petites notes crémeuses. column3: United States;Tripel;5 Seasons North;Appearance: Pours out a lightly hazed
column4: golden body with a thin layer of white foam that dissipated out fairly quickly. Smell: Sweetish nose of pils malt dipped in golden syrup and punctuated by some alcohol and fragrant white peach tones and fainter notes of spice and citrus. Taste: Sweet tastes of pilsner and pale malts boosted further by some candi sugar influences and a perceived taste of wildflower honey. In rolls a warming alcoholic quality and taste of peaches
column5: giving it a taste of fine peach schnapps. Hint of lemony citrus. Spicy flavor reminiscent of dried coriander. No more than a tiny bit of bitterness. Continually drying and warming right up until the semi-dry finish with a last
column6: final dose of spice and fruitiness. Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. There’s a definite stickiness to mouthfeel
column7: but thankfully it’s amply carbonated to keep it from ever becoming cloying. Drinkability: A sweet
column8: rich tripel that added a nice
column9: complimentary counterbalance to the beer battered onion rings and its spicy curry dipping sauce.
